questions.question_text:
You are troubleshooting a security issue for an Azure Storage account.

You enable Azure Storage Analytics logs and archive it to a storage account.

What should you use to retrieve the diagnostics logs?

discussion.content: If i had a penny for every time I'd seen this question, I can even recite the question and answer in my sleep now :D
Hooray, I've missed this question!
out of 485 questions, this question has been repeated nearly 30 times :)

The answer is C.
According to Microsoft Copilot:
For retrieving diagnostic logs, Azure Monitor is the most suitable option. It is specifically designed for collecting, analyzing, and acting on telemetry data from Azure services, including diagnostic logs. Azure Monitor allows you to configure diagnostic settings to send log data to various destinations and provides tools for analyzing and querying the data1.

Azure Storage Explorer is a useful tool for managing Azure Storage resources, and while it can be used to view logs stored in blob containers, it doesn’t offer the same level of monitoring and analysis capabilities as Azure Monitor2.

comments.content: We're asked to "retrieve", not "analyze", the logs.

discussion.content: wrong all of you it is azure monitor. It isn't azure storage explorer because Azure Storage Explorer can be used to view the $logs container where the diagnostics logs are stored. However, it cannot be used to analyze or query the logs themselves.

Selected Answer: D
D. Azure Storage Explorer

comments.content: AzCopy is in Azure Storage Explorer

discussion.content:
Soo this questions has two answers?
1- Azure Storage Explorer
2- AzCopy?

Selected Answer: D
D. Azure Storage Explorer

Selected Answer: D
D. Azure Storage Explorer
Correct answer is D. . Azure Storage Explorer
Reponse D

Selected Answer: D
D. Azure Storage Explorer

questions.question_text:
You have an Azure subscription that contains a Microsoft Defender External Attack Surface Management (Defender EASM) resource named EASM1.

You review the Attack Surface Summary dashboard.

You need to identify the following insights:

• Deprecated technologies that are no longer supported
• Infrastructure that will soon expire

Which section of the dashboard should you review?

discussion.content: Correct C. Attack Surface Priorities, https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/external-attack-surface-management/understanding-dashboards
Yes, C is the correct answer

Selected Answer: C
Attack Surface Priorities

Selected Answer: C
Correct answer
 Link: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/external-attack-surface-management/understanding-dashboards
In exam 1/28/24
In exam, aug 2023

questions.question_text:
You have an Azure subscription.

You plan to deploy Microsoft Defender External Attack Surface Management (Defender EASM) to identify and monitor externally facing assets.

You create a new Defender EASM instance named EASM1.

What should you do next?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Given answer is correct
 https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/external-attack-surface-management/what-is-discovery

Selected Answer: D
To create a comprehensive mapping of your organization’s attack surface, the system first intakes known assets (known as "seeds") that are recursively scanned to discover more entities through their connections to a seed. 

From,
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/external-attack-surface-management/what-is-discovery

Selected Answer: C
It's D, first you create a Discovery group and then u add the seed
Wouldn't I need to create a custom attack surface (A) and add a discovery group (C) BEFORE I can import seeds (D)?
Correct!
Correct. See: https://jeffreyappel.nl/how-to-use-microsoft-defender-easm-external-attack-surface-management/

questions.question_text:
You have an Azure subscription that contains an Azure Key Vault Standard key vault named Vault1. Vault1 hosts a 2048-bit RSA key named key1.

You need to ensure that key1 is rotated every 90 days.

What should you do first?

choices.C: Upgrade Vault1 to Key Vault Premium.
choices.B: Modify the Access policies settings of Vault1.
choices.D: Recreate key1 as an EC key.

comments.content:
THis is for HSM
But for azure default keyvault
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/key-vault/keys/how-to-configure-key-rotation

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Given answer is correct 
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/key-vault/managed-hsm/key-rotation
A is correct!

Answer is A.

Automated key rotation in Managed HSM allows users to configure Managed HSM to automatically generate a new key version at a specified frequency. You can set a rotation policy to configure rotation for each individual key and optionally rotate keys on demand

questions.question_text:
You have an Azure subscription named Sub1 that has Security defaults disabled. The subscription contains the following users:

• Five users that have owner permissions for Sub1.
• Ten users that have owner permissions for Azure resources.

None of the users have multi-factor authentication (MFA) enabled.

Sub1 has the secure score as shown in the Secure Score exhibit. (Click the Secure Score tab.)

//IMG//


You plan to enable MFA for the following users:

• Five users that have owner permission for Sub1.
• Five users that have owner permissions for Azure resources.

By how many points will the secure score increase after you perform the planned changes?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Current score = [Score per resource] * [Number of healthy resources]

Five users that have owner permissions for Sub1 = 5 x 5/5
Five users that have owner permissions for Azure resources = 5 x 5/10
Total score = 5 + 2.5 = 7.5

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/defender-for-cloud/secure-score-security-controls

comments.content: i dont get it where do you find the numbers!? I look at all docs for ms!!

Sorry this does not make any sense.. where did you get the numbers from?
Cant find it in doc
Thank you mate for taking the time to explain! Really appreciate it!
